page.title: 10Local History in Yewdale 1
page.content: The history of the area is very much bound up with the extraction of minerals since early times. Copper had been taken from the{Coppermines Valley since the mid-16th Century, with more extensive workings right through until the end of the 19th Century. This industry led to a growth in population in the Coniston district, and an influx of Cornish miners with their traditional surnames that are still found today, e.g. Livesey. The extensive coppice woodlands in the area are a reminder of the past importance of{charcoal}burning in association with rich{iron ore}brought in from the Dalton area. The monks of {Furness Abbey}developed primitive smelting hearths, or 'bloomeries', in the Coniston valley, sited on the lake shore to take advantage of the easiest form of bulk transport.
